Hi!

During autumn last year, there was some discussion about predicting stock
market movements. I didn't offer any input at the time since I wasn't
currently involved in it, but I had done stock market predictions before
that discussion, and I'm trying it out again.

I'd like to ask what came of your experiments? What indicators did you
find useful? Did you ever find consistent out of bounds performers? What
fitness functions did you try out? 

Finding a strategy that doubles or even quadruples your money on the
training set it is as trivial as it is useless, unless it performs well
out of bounds - which is much harder. And in my experience, strategies
rarely do. Or they perform well for one out of bounds period (say 2003)
but poorly for another (say 2004).

As for my own experiments, I don't use a list of trading data for a given
stock, instead I input a number of running averages. For instance, I
might
input the following indicators (all calculated the day before the market
day that we're predicting);

CloseRate, CloseRateAvg7, CloseRateAvg14, HighestRate, HighestRateAvg7,
HighestRateAvg14 etc.

All values are normalized by dividing by CloseRateAvg200. Inputing price
information for the last X days might work, but it seems extremely short
term and volatile. I've found in previous experiments that using too many
inputs can lead to overfitting, where the strategy simply identifies a
number of instances in the training set where it's good to buy stock.
Those instances are never repeated out of bounds and the strategy is
useless. 

Technical Analyzis introduces a wide range of indicators, most of which
have worked poorly in my experiments. Possibly the simplest TA strategy
is
to buy when the short term average is higher than the long term average,
because that indicates that the stock is moving up, and to sell on the
opposite.

I'm hoping to open up the discussion again and see if there are any new
cool ideas floating around. The two indicators CloseRateAvg7,
CloseRateAvg14 open up for this type of strategy.

cheers,
mattias
